projectDesc.p: This version of the Folger Digital Texts encodes the edition of each play by Barbara Mowat and Paul Werstine in TEI Simple. The major goal of recasting the texts in this manner is to make them interoperable with a large corpus of early modern texts derived from the EEBO-TCP transcriptionss and encoded in TEI Simple with linguistic annotation.

For a full description of the encoding practices of the Folger Digital Texts consult their encodingDesc section. This version is completely faithful to the readings, orthogrgraphy, and punctuation of the source text. It uses a different XML encoding scheme, with occasional losses in expressiveness. The major differences are:
Number div are replaced by unnumbered divs
Lines of verse are marked in l, tags, lines of prose in ab
All xml:ids are corpuswide identifiers
Information from the participant description element particDesc in the teiHeader has been moved into a castList element in the front element
Each spoken word in the text has been linguistically annotated with a lemma and POS tag

refsDecl.p: Words, spaces, and punctuation characters are numbered sequentially, incremented by 10.

Most other elements begin with an element-specific prefix, followed by a reference to the Folger Through Line Number, a sequential numbering of the numbered lines in the text. If an element is inline with play text, it has the same line number as the line where it begins. If it begins on a line following play text, a decimal number is appended and incremented as necessary. If it falls between a speech prefix and the play text, a ".0" is appended to the value of the following line number.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Alarum. Enter Richard Plantagenet, Duke of York; Edward; Richard; Norfolk; Montague; Warwick; and Soldiers, all wearing the white rose.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: I wonder how the King escaped our hands.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: While we pursued the horsemen of the north,
He slyly stole away and left his men;
Whereat the great lord of Northumberland,
Whose warlike ears could never brook retreat,
Cheered up the drooping army; and himself,
Lord Clifford, and Lord Stafford, all abreast,
Charged our main battle’s front and, breaking in,
Were by the swords of common soldiers slain.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: Lord Stafford’s father, Duke of Buckingham,
Is either slain or wounded dangerous.
I cleft his beaver with a downright blow.
That this is true, father, behold his blood.

sp.speaker: MONTAGUE
sp.l: And, brother, here’s the Earl of Wiltshire’s blood,
Whom I encountered as the battles joined.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Speak thou for me, and tell them what I did.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Richard hath best deserved of all my sons.
But is your Grace dead, my lord of Somerset?

sp.speaker: NORFOLK
sp.l: Such hope have all the line of John of Gaunt!

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Thus do I hope to shake King Henry’s head.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: And so do I, victorious prince of York.
Before I see thee seated in that throne
Which now the house of Lancaster usurps,
I vow by heaven these eyes shall never close.
This is the palace of the fearful king,
And this the regal seat. Possess it, York,
For this is thine and not King Henry’s heirs’.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Assist me, then, sweet Warwick, and I will,
For hither we have broken in by force.

sp.speaker: NORFOLK
sp.l: We’ll all assist you. He that flies shall die.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Thanks, gentle Norfolk. Stay by me, my lords.—
And soldiers, stay and lodge by me this night.

div.stage: They go up onto a dais or platform.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: And when the King comes, offer him no violence
Unless he seek to thrust you out perforce.

div.stage: Soldiers exit or retire out of sight.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: The Queen this day here holds her parliament,
But little thinks we shall be of her council.
By words or blows, here let us win our right.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Armed as we are, let’s stay within this house.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: “ The Bloody Parliament” shall this be called
Unless Plantagenet, Duke of York, be king
And bashful Henry deposed, whose cowardice
Hath made us bywords to our enemies.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Then leave me not, my lords; be resolute.
I mean to take possession of my right.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Neither the King nor he that loves him best,
The proudest he that holds up Lancaster,
Dares stir a wing if Warwick shake his bells.
I’ll plant Plantagenet, root him up who dares.
Resolve thee, Richard; claim the English crown.

div.stage: York sits in the chair of state.
Flourish. Enter King Henry, Clifford, Northumberland, Westmorland, Exeter, and the rest, all wearing the red rose.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: My lords, look where the sturdy rebel sits,
Even in the chair of state! Belike he means,
Backed by the power of Warwick, that false peer,
To aspire unto the crown and reign as king.
Earl of Northumberland, he slew thy father,
And thine, Lord Clifford, and you both have vowed revenge
On him, his sons, his favorites, and his friends.

sp.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
sp.l: If I be not, heavens be revenged on me!

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: The hope thereof makes Clifford mourn in steel.

sp.speaker: WESTMORLAND
sp.l: What, shall we suffer this? Let’s pluck him down.
My heart for anger burns. I cannot brook it.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Be patient, gentle Earl of Westmorland.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Patience is for poltroons such as he.
He durst not sit there had your father lived.
My gracious lord, here in the Parliament
Let us assail the family of York.

sp.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
sp.l: Well hast thou spoken, cousin. Be it so.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Ah, know you not the city favors them,
And they have troops of soldiers at their beck?

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: But when the Duke is slain, they’ll quickly fly.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Far be the thought of this from Henry’s heart,
To make a shambles of the Parliament House!
Cousin of Exeter, frowns, words, and threats
Shall be the war that Henry means to use.—
Thou factious Duke of York, descend my throne
And kneel for grace and mercy at my feet.
I am thy sovereign.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: I am thine.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: For shame, come down. He made thee Duke of York.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: It was my inheritance, as the earldom was.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: Thy father was a traitor to the crown.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Exeter, thou art a traitor to the crown
In following this usurping Henry.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Whom should he follow but his natural king?

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: True, Clifford, that’s Richard, Duke of York.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: And shall I stand, and thou sit in my throne?

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: It must and shall be so. Content thyself.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Be Duke of Lancaster. Let him be king.

sp.speaker: WESTMORLAND
sp.l: He is both king and Duke of Lancaster,
And that the lord of Westmorland shall maintain.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: And Warwick shall disprove it. You forget
That we are those which chased you from the field
And slew your fathers and, with colors spread,
Marched through the city to the palace gates.

sp.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
sp.l: Yes, Warwick, I remember it to my grief;
And by his soul, thou and thy house shall rue it.

sp.speaker: WESTMORLAND
sp.l: Plantagenet, of thee and these thy sons,
Thy kinsmen, and thy friends, I’ll have more lives
Than drops of blood were in my father’s veins.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Urge it no more, lest that, instead of words,
I send thee, Warwick, such a messenger
As shall revenge his death before I stir.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Poor Clifford, how I scorn his worthless threats!

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Will you we show our title to the crown?
If not, our swords shall plead it in the field.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: What title hast thou, traitor, to the crown?
Thy father was as thou art, Duke of York;
Thy grandfather, Roger Mortimer, Earl of March.
I am the son of Henry the Fifth,
Who made the Dauphin and the French to stoop
And seized upon their towns and provinces.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Talk not of France, sith thou hast lost it all.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: The Lord Protector lost it and not I.
When I was crowned, I was but nine months old.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: You are old enough now, and yet, methinks, you lose.—
Father, tear the crown from the usurper’s head.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: Sweet father, do so. Set it on your head.

sp.speaker: MONTAGUE
sp.l: Good brother, as thou lov’st and honorest arms,
Let’s fight it out and not stand caviling thus.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Sound drums and trumpets, and the King will fly.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Sons, peace!

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Peace thou, and give King Henry leave to speak!

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Plantagenet shall speak first. Hear him, lords,
And be you silent and attentive too,
For he that interrupts him shall not live.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Think’st thou that I will leave my kingly throne,
Wherein my grandsire and my father sat?
No. First shall war unpeople this my realm;
Ay, and their colors, often borne in France,
And now in England to our heart’s great sorrow,
Shall be my winding-sheet. Why faint you, lords?
My title’s good, and better far than his.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Prove it, Henry, and thou shalt be king.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Henry the Fourth by conquest got the crown.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: ’Twas by rebellion against his king.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: I know not what to say; my title’s weak.—
Tell me, may not a king adopt an heir?

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: An if he may, then am I lawful king;
For Richard, in the view of many lords,
Resigned the crown to Henry the Fourth,
Whose heir my father was, and I am his.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: He rose against him, being his sovereign,
And made him to resign his crown perforce.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Suppose, my lords, he did it unconstrained,
Think you ’twere prejudicial to his crown?

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: No, for he could not so resign his crown
But that the next heir should succeed and reign.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Art thou against us, Duke of Exeter?

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: His is the right, and therefore pardon me.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Why whisper you, my lords, and answer not?

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: My conscience tells me he is lawful king.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: All will revolt from me and turn to him.

sp.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
sp.l: Plantagenet, for all the claim thou lay’st,
Think not that Henry shall be so deposed.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Deposed he shall be, in despite of all.

sp.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
sp.l: Thou art deceived. ’Tis not thy southern power
Of Essex, Norfolk, Suffolk, nor of Kent,
Which makes thee thus presumptuous and proud,
Can set the Duke up in despite of me.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: King Henry, be thy title right or wrong,
Lord Clifford vows to fight in thy defense.
May that ground gape and swallow me alive
Where I shall kneel to him that slew my father.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: O Clifford, how thy words revive my heart!

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Henry of Lancaster, resign thy crown.—
What mutter you, or what conspire you, lords?

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Do right unto this princely Duke of York,
Or I will fill the house with armèd men,
And over the chair of state, where now he sits,
Write up his title with usurping blood.

div.stage: He stamps with his foot, and the Soldiers show themselves.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: My lord of Warwick, hear but one word:
Let me for this my lifetime reign as king.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Confirm the crown to me and to mine heirs,
And thou shalt reign in quiet while thou liv’st.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: I am content. Richard Plantagenet,
Enjoy the kingdom after my decease.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: What wrong is this unto the Prince your son!

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: What good is this to England and himself!

sp.speaker: WESTMORLAND
sp.l: Base, fearful, and despairing Henry!

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: How hast thou injured both thyself and us!

sp.speaker: WESTMORLAND
sp.l: I cannot stay to hear these articles.

sp.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Come, cousin, let us tell the Queen these news.

sp.speaker: WESTMORLAND
sp.l: Farewell, faint-hearted and degenerate king,
In whose cold blood no spark of honor bides.

sp.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
sp.l: Be thou a prey unto the house of York,
And die in bands for this unmanly deed.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: In dreadful war mayst thou be overcome,
Or live in peace abandoned and despised!

div.stage: Westmorland, Northumberland, Clifford, and their Soldiers exit.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Turn this way, Henry, and regard them not.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: They seek revenge and therefore will not yield.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Ah, Exeter!

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Why should you sigh, my lord?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Not for myself, Lord Warwick, but my son,
Whom I unnaturally shall disinherit.
But be it as it may. ( To York.) I here entail
The crown to thee and to thine heirs forever,
Conditionally, that here thou take an oath
To cease this civil war and, whilst I live,
To honor me as thy king and sovereign,
And neither by treason nor hostility
To seek to put me down and reign thyself.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: This oath I willingly take and will perform.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Long live King Henry! Plantagenet, embrace him.

div.stage: York stands, and King Henry ascends the dais.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: And long live thou and these thy forward sons!

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Now York and Lancaster are reconciled.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: Accursed be he that seeks to make them foes.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Farewell, my gracious lord. I’ll to my castle.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: And I’ll keep London with my soldiers.

sp.speaker: NORFOLK
sp.l: And I to Norfolk with my followers.

sp.speaker: MONTAGUE
sp.l: And I unto the sea, from whence I came.

div.stage: York, Edward, Richard, Warwick, Norfolk, Montague, and their Soldiers exit.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: And I with grief and sorrow to the court.

div.stage: Enter Queen Margaret, with Prince Edward.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: Here comes the Queen, whose looks bewray her anger.
I’ll steal away.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Exeter, so will I.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Nay, go not from me. I will follow thee.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Be patient, gentle queen, and I will stay.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Who can be patient in such extremes?
Ah, wretched man, would I had died a maid
And never seen thee, never borne thee son,
Seeing thou hast proved so unnatural a father.
Hath he deserved to lose his birthright thus?
Hadst thou but loved him half so well as I,
Or felt that pain which I did for him once,
Or nourished him as I did with my blood,
Thou wouldst have left thy dearest heart-blood there,
Rather than have made that savage duke thine heir
And disinherited thine only son.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.l: Father, you cannot disinherit me.
If you be king, why should not I succeed?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Pardon me, Margaret.— Pardon me, sweet son.
The Earl of Warwick and the Duke enforced me.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Enforced thee? Art thou king and wilt be forced?
I shame to hear thee speak. Ah, timorous wretch,
Thou hast undone thyself, thy son, and me,
And giv’n unto the house of York such head
As thou shalt reign but by their sufferance!
To entail him and his heirs unto the crown,
What is it but to make thy sepulcher
And creep into it far before thy time?
Warwick is Chancellor and the lord of Callice;
Stern Falconbridge commands the Narrow Seas;
The Duke is made Protector of the realm;
And yet shalt thou be safe? Such safety finds
The trembling lamb environèd with wolves.
Had I been there, which am a silly woman,
The soldiers should have tossed me on their pikes
Before I would have granted to that act.
But thou preferr’st thy life before thine honor.
And seeing thou dost, I here divorce myself
Both from thy table, Henry, and thy bed,
Until that act of Parliament be repealed
Whereby my son is disinherited.
The northern lords that have forsworn thy colors
Will follow mine if once they see them spread;
And spread they shall be, to thy foul disgrace
And utter ruin of the house of York.
Thus do I leave thee.— Come, son, let’s away.
Our army is ready. Come, we’ll after them.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Stay, gentle Margaret, and hear me speak.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Thou hast spoke too much already. Get thee gone.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Gentle son Edward, thou wilt stay with me?

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Ay, to be murdered by his enemies!

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.l: When I return with victory from the field,
I’ll see your Grace. Till then, I’ll follow her.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Come, son, away. We may not linger thus.

div.stage: Queen Margaret and Prince Edward exit.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Poor queen! How love to me and to her son
Hath made her break out into terms of rage!
Revenged may she be on that hateful duke,
Whose haughty spirit, wingèd with desire,
Will cost my crown, and like an empty eagle
Tire on the flesh of me and of my son.
The loss of those three lords torments my heart.
I’ll write unto them and entreat them fair.
Come, cousin, you shall be the messenger.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: And I, I hope, shall reconcile them all.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter Richard, Edward, and Montague, all wearing the white rose.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Brother, though I be youngest, give me leave.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: No, I can better play the orator.

sp.speaker: MONTAGUE
sp.l: But I have reasons strong and forcible.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Why, how now, sons and brother, at a strife?
What is your quarrel? How began it first?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: No quarrel, but a slight contention.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: About what?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: About that which concerns your Grace and us:
The crown of England, father, which is yours.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Mine, boy? Not till King Henry be dead.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Your right depends not on his life or death.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: Now you are heir; therefore enjoy it now.
By giving the house of Lancaster leave to breathe,
It will outrun you, father, in the end.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: I took an oath that he should quietly reign.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: But for a kingdom any oath may be broken.
I would break a thousand oaths to reign one year.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: No, God forbid your Grace should be forsworn.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: I shall be, if I claim by open war.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: I’ll prove the contrary, if you’ll hear me speak.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Thou canst not, son; it is impossible.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: An oath is of no moment, being not took
Before a true and lawful magistrate
That hath authority over him that swears.
Henry had none, but did usurp the place.
Then, seeing ’twas he that made you to depose,
Your oath, my lord, is vain and frivolous.
Therefore, to arms! And, father, do but think
How sweet a thing it is to wear a crown,
Within whose circuit is Elysium
And all that poets feign of bliss and joy.
Why do we linger thus? I cannot rest
Until the white rose that I wear be dyed
Even in the lukewarm blood of Henry’s heart.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Richard, enough. I will be king or die.—
Brother, thou shalt to London presently,
And whet on Warwick to this enterprise.—
Thou, Richard, shalt to the Duke of Norfolk
And tell him privily of our intent.—
You, Edward, shall unto my Lord Cobham,
With whom the Kentishmen will willingly rise;
In them I trust, for they are soldiers
Witty, courteous, liberal, full of spirit.
While you are thus employed, what resteth more
But that I seek occasion how to rise,
And yet the King not privy to my drift,
Nor any of the house of Lancaster.
But stay, what news? Why com’st thou in such post?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: The Queen with all the northern earls and lords
Intend here to besiege you in your castle.
She is hard by with twenty thousand men.
And therefore fortify your hold, my lord.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Ay, with my sword. What, think’st thou that we fear them?—
Edward and Richard, you shall stay with me;
My brother Montague shall post to London.
Let noble Warwick, Cobham, and the rest,
Whom we have left Protectors of the King,
With powerful policy strengthen themselves
And trust not simple Henry nor his oaths.

sp.speaker: MONTAGUE
sp.l: Brother, I go. I’ll win them, fear it not.
And thus most humbly I do take my leave.

div.stage: Enter Sir John Mortimer, and his brother, Sir Hugh Mortimer.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Sir John and Sir Hugh Mortimer, mine uncles,
You are come to Sandal in a happy hour.
The army of the Queen mean to besiege us.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN
sp.l: She shall not need; we’ll meet her in the field.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: What, with five thousand men?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Ay, with five hundred, father, for a need.
A woman’s general; what should we fear?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: I hear their drums. Let’s set our men in order,
And issue forth and bid them battle straight.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Five men to twenty: though the odds be great,
I doubt not, uncle, of our victory.
Many a battle have I won in France
Whenas the enemy hath been ten to one.
Why should I not now have the like success?

div.head: Scene 3

sp.speaker: RUTLAND
sp.l: Ah, whither shall I fly to scape their hands?
sp.stage: Enter Clifford with Soldiers, all wearing the red rose.
sp.l: Ah, tutor, look where bloody Clifford comes.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Chaplain, away. Thy priesthood saves thy life.
As for the brat of this accursèd duke,
Whose father slew my father, he shall die.

sp.speaker: TUTOR
sp.l: And I, my lord, will bear him company.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Soldiers, away with him.

sp.speaker: TUTOR
sp.l: Ah, Clifford, murder not this innocent child,
Lest thou be hated both of God and man.

div.stage: He exits, dragged off by Soldiers.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: How now? Is he dead already? Or is it fear
That makes him close his eyes? I’ll open them.

sp.speaker: RUTLAND
sp.l: So looks the pent-up lion o’er the wretch
That trembles under his devouring paws;
And so he walks, insulting o’er his prey;
And so he comes to rend his limbs asunder.
Ah, gentle Clifford, kill me with thy sword
And not with such a cruel threat’ning look.
Sweet Clifford, hear me speak before I die.
I am too mean a subject for thy wrath.
Be thou revenged on men, and let me live.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: In vain thou speak’st, poor boy. My father’s blood
Hath stopped the passage where thy words should enter.

sp.speaker: RUTLAND
sp.l: Then let my father’s blood open it again;
He is a man and, Clifford, cope with him.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Had I thy brethren here, their lives and thine
Were not revenge sufficient for me.
No, if I digged up thy forefathers’ graves
And hung their rotten coffins up in chains,
It could not slake mine ire nor ease my heart.
The sight of any of the house of York
Is as a fury to torment my soul,
And till I root out their accursèd line
And leave not one alive, I live in hell.
Therefore—

sp.speaker: RUTLAND
sp.l: O, let me pray before I take my death!
To thee I pray: sweet Clifford, pity me!

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Such pity as my rapier’s point affords.

sp.speaker: RUTLAND
sp.l: I never did thee harm. Why wilt thou slay me?

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Thy father hath.

sp.speaker: RUTLAND
sp.l: But ’twas ere I was born.
Thou hast one son; for his sake pity me,
Lest in revenge thereof, sith God is just,
He be as miserably slain as I.
Ah, let me live in prison all my days,
And when I give occasion of offense
Then let me die, for now thou hast no cause.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: No cause? Thy father slew my father; therefore die.

sp.speaker: RUTLAND
sp.l: Di faciant laudis summa sit ista tuae!

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Plantagenet, I come, Plantagenet!
And this thy son’s blood, cleaving to my blade,
Shall rust upon my weapon till thy blood,
Congealed with this, do make me wipe off both.

div.stage: He exits, with Soldiers carrying off Rutland’s body.

div.head: Scene 4
div.stage: Alarum. Enter Richard, Duke of York, wearing the white rose.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: The army of the Queen hath got the field.
My uncles both are slain in rescuing me;
And all my followers to the eager foe
Turn back and fly like ships before the wind,
Or lambs pursued by hunger-starvèd wolves.
My sons, God knows what hath bechancèd them;
But this I know: they have demeaned themselves
Like men borne to renown by life or death.
Three times did Richard make a lane to me
And thrice cried “ Courage, father, fight it out!”
And full as oft came Edward to my side,
With purple falchion painted to the hilt
In blood of those that had encountered him;
And when the hardiest warriors did retire,
Richard cried “ Charge, and give no foot of ground!”
And cried “ A crown or else a glorious tomb;
A scepter or an earthly sepulcher!”
With this we charged again; but, out alas,
We budged again, as I have seen a swan
With bootless labor swim against the tide
And spend her strength with over-matching waves.
Ah, hark, the fatal followers do pursue,
And I am faint and cannot fly their fury;
And were I strong, I would not shun their fury.
The sands are numbered that makes up my life.
Here must I stay, and here my life must end.
sp.stage: Enter Queen Margaret, Clifford, Northumberland, the young Prince Edward, and Soldiers, all wearing the red rose.
sp.l: Come, bloody Clifford, rough Northumberland,
I dare your quenchless fury to more rage.
I am your butt, and I abide your shot.

sp.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
sp.l: Yield to our mercy, proud Plantagenet.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Ay, to such mercy as his ruthless arm
With downright payment showed unto my father.
Now Phaëton hath tumbled from his car
And made an evening at the noontide prick.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: My ashes, as the Phoenix’, may bring forth
A bird that will revenge upon you all;
And in that hope I throw mine eyes to heaven,
Scorning whate’er you can afflict me with.
Why come you not? What, multitudes, and fear?

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: So cowards fight when they can fly no further;
So doves do peck the falcon’s piercing talons;
So desperate thieves, all hopeless of their lives,
Breathe out invectives ’gainst the officers.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: O Clifford, but bethink thee once again
And in thy thought o’errun my former time;
And, if thou canst for blushing, view this face
And bite thy tongue that slanders him with cowardice
Whose frown hath made thee faint and fly ere this.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: I will not bandy with thee word for word,
But buckler with thee blows twice two for one.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Hold, valiant Clifford, for a thousand causes
I would prolong a while the traitor’s life.—
Wrath makes him deaf; speak thou, Northumberland.

sp.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
sp.l: Hold, Clifford, do not honor him so much
To prick thy finger, though to wound his heart.
What valor were it when a cur doth grin
For one to thrust his hand between his teeth,
When he might spurn him with his foot away?
It is war’s prize to take all vantages,
And ten to one is no impeach of valor.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Ay, ay, so strives the woodcock with the gin.

sp.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
sp.l: So doth the coney struggle in the net.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: So triumph thieves upon their conquered booty;
So true men yield with robbers, so o’ermatched.

sp.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
sp.l: What would your Grace have done unto him now?

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Brave warriors, Clifford and Northumberland,
Come, make him stand upon this molehill here
That raught at mountains with outstretchèd arms,
Yet parted but the shadow with his hand.
sp.stage: They place York on a small prominence.
sp.l: What, was it you that would be England’s king?
Was ’t you that reveled in our parliament
And made a preachment of your high descent?
Where are your mess of sons to back you now,
The wanton Edward and the lusty George?
And where’s that valiant crookback prodigy,
Dickie, your boy, that with his grumbling voice
Was wont to cheer his dad in mutinies?
Or, with the rest, where is your darling Rutland?
Look, York, I stained this napkin with the blood
That valiant Clifford with his rapier’s point
Made issue from the bosom of the boy;
And if thine eyes can water for his death,
I give thee this to dry thy cheeks withal.
sp.stage: She gives him a bloody cloth.
sp.l: Alas, poor York, but that I hate thee deadly
I should lament thy miserable state.
I prithee grieve to make me merry, York.
What, hath thy fiery heart so parched thine entrails
That not a tear can fall for Rutland’s death?
Why art thou patient, man? Thou shouldst be mad;
And I, to make thee mad, do mock thee thus.
Stamp, rave, and fret, that I may sing and dance.
Thou would’st be fee’d, I see, to make me sport.—
York cannot speak unless he wear a crown.
A crown for York!
sp.stage: She is handed a paper crown.
sp.l: And, lords, bow low to him.
Hold you his hands whilst I do set it on.
sp.stage: She puts the crown on York’s head.
sp.l: Ay, marry, sir, now looks he like a king.
Ay, this is he that took King Henry’s chair,
And this is he was his adopted heir.
But how is it that great Plantagenet
Is crowned so soon and broke his solemn oath?—
As I bethink me, you should not be king
Till our King Henry had shook hands with Death.
And will you pale your head in Henry’s glory
And rob his temples of the diadem
Now, in his life, against your holy oath?
O, ’tis a fault too too unpardonable.
Off with the crown and, with the crown, his head;
And whilst we breathe, take time to do him dead.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: That is my office, for my father’s sake.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Nay, stay, let’s hear the orisons he makes.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: She-wolf of France, but worse than wolves of France,
Whose tongue more poisons than the adder’s tooth:
How ill-beseeming is it in thy sex
To triumph like an Amazonian trull
Upon their woes whom Fortune captivates.
But that thy face is vizard-like, unchanging,
Made impudent with use of evil deeds,
I would assay, proud queen, to make thee blush.
To tell thee whence thou cam’st, of whom derived,
Were shame enough to shame thee, wert thou not shameless.
Thy father bears the type of King of Naples,
Of both the Sicils, and Jerusalem,
Yet not so wealthy as an English yeoman.
Hath that poor monarch taught thee to insult?
It needs not, nor it boots thee not, proud queen,
Unless the adage must be verified
That beggars mounted run their horse to death.
’Tis beauty that doth oft make women proud,
But God He knows thy share thereof is small.
’Tis virtue that doth make them most admired;
The contrary doth make thee wondered at.
’Tis government that makes them seem divine;
The want thereof makes thee abominable.
Thou art as opposite to every good
As the Antipodes are unto us
Or as the south to the Septentrion.
O, tiger’s heart wrapped in a woman’s hide,
How couldst thou drain the lifeblood of the child
To bid the father wipe his eyes withal,
And yet be seen to bear a woman’s face?
Women are soft, mild, pitiful, and flexible;
Thou, stern, obdurate, flinty, rough, remorseless.
Bidd’st thou me rage? Why, now thou hast thy wish.
Wouldst have me weep? Why, now thou hast thy will;
For raging wind blows up incessant showers,
And when the rage allays, the rain begins.
These tears are my sweet Rutland’s obsequies,
And every drop cries vengeance for his death
’Gainst thee, fell Clifford, and thee, false Frenchwoman!

sp.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
sp.l: Beshrew me, but his passions moves me so
That hardly can I check my eyes from tears.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: That face of his the hungry cannibals
Would not have touched, would not have stained with blood;
But you are more inhuman, more inexorable,
O, ten times more than tigers of Hyrcania.
See, ruthless queen, a hapless father’s tears.
This cloth thou dipped’st in blood of my sweet boy,
And I with tears do wash the blood away.
Keep thou the napkin and go boast of this;
And if thou tell’st the heavy story right,
Upon my soul, the hearers will shed tears.
Yea, even my foes will shed fast-falling tears
And say “ Alas, it was a piteous deed.”
sp.stage: He hands her the paper crown.
sp.l: There, take the crown and, with the crown, my curse,
And in thy need such comfort come to thee
As now I reap at thy too cruel hand.—
Hard-hearted Clifford, take me from the world,
My soul to heaven, my blood upon your heads.

sp.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
sp.l: Had he been slaughterman to all my kin,
I should not for my life but weep with him
To see how inly sorrow gripes his soul.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: What, weeping ripe, my Lord Northumberland?
Think but upon the wrong he did us all,
And that will quickly dry thy melting tears.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Here’s for my oath; here’s for my father’s death!

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: And here’s to right our gentle-hearted king.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: Open thy gate of mercy, gracious God.
My soul flies through these wounds to seek out Thee.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Off with his head, and set it on York gates,
So York may overlook the town of York.

div.stage: Flourish. They exit, Soldiers carrying York’s body.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: A march. Enter Edward, Richard, and their power, all wearing the white rose.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: I wonder how our princely father scaped,
Or whether he be scaped away or no
From Clifford’s and Northumberland’s pursuit.
Had he been ta’en, we should have heard the news;
Had he been slain, we should have heard the news;
Or had he scaped, methinks we should have heard
The happy tidings of his good escape.
How fares my brother? Why is he so sad?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: I cannot joy until I be resolved
Where our right valiant father is become.
I saw him in the battle range about
And watched him how he singled Clifford forth.
Methought he bore him in the thickest troop
As doth a lion in a herd of neat,
Or as a bear encompassed round with dogs,
Who having pinched a few and made them cry,
The rest stand all aloof and bark at him;
So fared our father with his enemies;
So fled his enemies my warlike father.
Methinks ’tis prize enough to be his son.
See how the morning opes her golden gates
And takes her farewell of the glorious sun.
How well resembles it the prime of youth,
Trimmed like a younker, prancing to his love!

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: Dazzle mine eyes, or do I see three suns?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Three glorious suns, each one a perfect sun,
Not separated with the racking clouds
But severed in a pale clear-shining sky.
See, see, they join, embrace, and seem to kiss,
As if they vowed some league inviolable.
Now are they but one lamp, one light, one sun;
In this, the heaven figures some event.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: ’Tis wondrous strange, the like yet never heard of.
I think it cites us, brother, to the field,
That we, the sons of brave Plantagenet,
Each one already blazing by our meeds,
Should notwithstanding join our lights together
And overshine the earth, as this the world.
Whate’er it bodes, henceforward will I bear
Upon my target three fair shining suns.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Nay, bear three daughters: by your leave I speak it,
You love the breeder better than the male.
But what art thou whose heavy looks foretell
Some dreadful story hanging on thy tongue?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Ah, one that was a woeful looker-on
Whenas the noble Duke of York was slain,
Your princely father and my loving lord.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: O, speak no more, for I have heard too much!

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Say how he died, for I will hear it all.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Environèd he was with many foes,
And stood against them, as the hope of Troy
Against the Greeks that would have entered Troy.
But Hercules himself must yield to odds;
And many strokes, though with a little axe,
Hews down and fells the hardest-timbered oak.
By many hands your father was subdued,
But only slaughtered by the ireful arm
Of unrelenting Clifford and the Queen,
Who crowned the gracious duke in high despite,
Laughed in his face; and when with grief he wept,
The ruthless queen gave him to dry his cheeks
A napkin steepèd in the harmless blood
Of sweet young Rutland, by rough Clifford slain.
And after many scorns, many foul taunts,
They took his head and on the gates of York
They set the same, and there it doth remain,
The saddest spectacle that e’er I viewed.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: Sweet Duke of York, our prop to lean upon,
Now thou art gone, we have no staff, no stay.
O Clifford, boist’rous Clifford, thou hast slain
The flower of Europe for his chivalry;
And treacherously hast thou vanquished him,
For hand to hand he would have vanquished thee.
Now my soul’s palace is become a prison;
Ah, would she break from hence, that this my body
Might in the ground be closèd up in rest,
For never henceforth shall I joy again.
Never, O never, shall I see more joy!

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: I cannot weep, for all my body’s moisture
Scarce serves to quench my furnace-burning heart;
Nor can my tongue unload my heart’s great burden,
For selfsame wind that I should speak withal
Is kindling coals that fires all my breast
And burns me up with flames that tears would quench.
To weep is to make less the depth of grief:
Tears, then, for babes; blows and revenge for me.
Richard, I bear thy name. I’ll venge thy death
Or die renownèd by attempting it.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: His name that valiant duke hath left with thee;
His dukedom and his chair with me is left.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Nay, if thou be that princely eagle’s bird,
Show thy descent by gazing ’gainst the sun;
For “ chair” and “ dukedom,” “ throne” and “ kingdom” say;
Either that is thine or else thou wert not his.

div.stage: March. Enter Warwick, Marquess Montague, and their army, all wearing the white rose.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: How now, fair lords? What fare, what news abroad?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Great lord of Warwick, if we should recount
Our baleful news, and at each word’s deliverance
Stab poniards in our flesh till all were told,
The words would add more anguish than the wounds.
O valiant lord, the Duke of York is slain.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: O Warwick, Warwick, that Plantagenet
Which held thee dearly as his soul’s redemption
Is by the stern Lord Clifford done to death.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Ten days ago I drowned these news in tears.
And now to add more measure to your woes,
I come to tell you things sith then befall’n.
After the bloody fray at Wakefield fought,
Where your brave father breathed his latest gasp,
Tidings, as swiftly as the posts could run,
Were brought me of your loss and his depart.
I, then in London, keeper of the King,
Mustered my soldiers, gathered flocks of friends,
Marched toward Saint Albans to intercept the Queen,
Bearing the King in my behalf along;
For by my scouts I was advertisèd
That she was coming with a full intent
To dash our late decree in Parliament
Touching King Henry’s oath and your succession.
Short tale to make, we at Saint Albans met,
Our battles joined, and both sides fiercely fought.
But whether ’twas the coldness of the King,
Who looked full gently on his warlike queen,
That robbed my soldiers of their heated spleen,
Or whether ’twas report of her success
Or more than common fear of Clifford’s rigor,
Who thunders to his captives blood and death,
I cannot judge; but to conclude with truth,
Their weapons like to lightning came and went;
Our soldiers’, like the night owl’s lazy flight
Or like an idle thresher with a flail,
Fell gently down, as if they struck their friends.
I cheered them up with justice of our cause,
With promise of high pay and great rewards,
But all in vain; they had no heart to fight,
And we, in them, no hope to win the day,
So that we fled: the King unto the Queen;
Lord George your brother, Norfolk, and myself
In haste, posthaste, are come to join with you;
For in the Marches here we heard you were,
Making another head to fight again.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: Where is the Duke of Norfolk, gentle Warwick?
And when came George from Burgundy to England?

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Some six miles off the Duke is with the soldiers,
And, for your brother, he was lately sent
From your kind aunt, Duchess of Burgundy,
With aid of soldiers to this needful war.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: ’Twas odds, belike, when valiant Warwick fled.
Oft have I heard his praises in pursuit,
But ne’er till now his scandal of retire.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Nor now my scandal, Richard, dost thou hear?
For thou shalt know this strong right hand of mine
Can pluck the diadem from faint Henry’s head
And wring the awful scepter from his fist,
Were he as famous and as bold in war
As he is famed for mildness, peace, and prayer.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: I know it well, Lord Warwick; blame me not.
’Tis love I bear thy glories make me speak.
But in this troublous time, what’s to be done?
Shall we go throw away our coats of steel
And wrap our bodies in black mourning gowns,
Numb’ring our Ave Marys with our beads?
Or shall we on the helmets of our foes
Tell our devotion with revengeful arms?
If for the last, say “ Ay,” and to it, lords.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Why, therefore Warwick came to seek you out,
And therefore comes my brother Montague.
Attend me, lords: the proud insulting queen,
With Clifford and the haught Northumberland
And of their feather many more proud birds,
Have wrought the easy-melting king like wax.
He swore consent to your succession,
His oath enrollèd in the Parliament.
And now to London all the crew are gone
To frustrate both his oath and what beside
May make against the house of Lancaster.
Their power, I think, is thirty thousand strong.
Now, if the help of Norfolk and myself,
With all the friends that thou, brave Earl of March,
Amongst the loving Welshmen canst procure,
Will but amount to five and twenty thousand,
Why, via, to London will we march,
And once again bestride our foaming steeds,
And once again cry “ Charge!” upon our foes,
But never once again turn back and fly.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Ay, now methinks I hear great Warwick speak.
Ne’er may he live to see a sunshine day
That cries “ Retire!” if Warwick bid him stay.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: Lord Warwick, on thy shoulder will I lean,
And when thou fail’st— as God forbid the hour!—
Must Edward fall, which peril heaven forfend.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: No longer Earl of March, but Duke of York;
The next degree is England’s royal throne:
For King of England shalt thou be proclaimed
In every borough as we pass along,
And he that throws not up his cap for joy
Shall for the fault make forfeit of his head.
King Edward, valiant Richard, Montague,
Stay we no longer dreaming of renown,
But sound the trumpets and about our task.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Then, Clifford, were thy heart as hard as steel,
As thou hast shown it flinty by thy deeds,
I come to pierce it or to give thee mine.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: Then strike up drums! God and Saint George for us!

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: How now, what news?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: The Duke of Norfolk sends you word by me,
The Queen is coming with a puissant host,
And craves your company for speedy counsel.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Why, then it sorts. Brave warriors, let’s away!

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Flourish. Enter King Henry, Queen Margaret, Clifford, Northumberland, and young Prince Edward, all wearing the red rose with Drum and Trumpets, the head of York fixed above them.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Welcome, my lord, to this brave town of York.
Yonder’s the head of that arch-enemy
That sought to be encompassed with your crown.
Doth not the object cheer your heart, my lord?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Ay, as the rocks cheer them that fear their wrack!
To see this sight, it irks my very soul.
Withhold revenge, dear God! ’Tis not my fault,
Nor wittingly have I infringed my vow.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: My gracious liege, this too much lenity
And harmful pity must be laid aside.
To whom do lions cast their gentle looks?
Not to the beast that would usurp their den.
Whose hand is that the forest bear doth lick?
Not his that spoils her young before her face.
Who scapes the lurking serpent’s mortal sting?
Not he that sets his foot upon her back.
The smallest worm will turn, being trodden on,
And doves will peck in safeguard of their brood.
Ambitious York did level at thy crown,
Thou smiling while he knit his angry brows.
He, but a duke, would have his son a king
And raise his issue like a loving sire;
Thou being a king, blest with a goodly son,
Didst yield consent to disinherit him,
Which argued thee a most unloving father.
Unreasonable creatures feed their young;
And though man’s face be fearful to their eyes,
Yet in protection of their tender ones,
Who hath not seen them, even with those wings
Which sometime they have used with fearful flight,
Make war with him that climbed unto their nest,
Offering their own lives in their young’s defense?
For shame, my liege, make them your precedent.
Were it not pity that this goodly boy
Should lose his birthright by his father’s fault,
And long hereafter say unto his child
“ What my great-grandfather and grandsire got,
My careless father fondly gave away”?
Ah, what a shame were this! Look on the boy,
And let his manly face, which promiseth
Successful fortune, steel thy melting heart
To hold thine own and leave thine own with him.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Full well hath Clifford played the orator,
Inferring arguments of mighty force.
But, Clifford, tell me, didst thou never hear
That things ill got had ever bad success?
And happy always was it for that son
Whose father for his hoarding went to hell?
I’ll leave my son my virtuous deeds behind,
And would my father had left me no more;
For all the rest is held at such a rate
As brings a thousandfold more care to keep
Than in possession any jot of pleasure.
Ah, cousin York, would thy best friends did know
How it doth grieve me that thy head is here.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: My lord, cheer up your spirits; our foes are nigh,
And this soft courage makes your followers faint.
You promised knighthood to our forward son.
Unsheathe your sword and dub him presently.—
Edward, kneel down.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Edward Plantagenet, arise a knight,
And learn this lesson: draw thy sword in right.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.l: My gracious father, by your kingly leave,
I’ll draw it as apparent to the crown
And in that quarrel use it to the death.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Why, that is spoken like a toward prince.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Royal commanders, be in readiness,
For with a band of thirty thousand men
Comes Warwick backing of the Duke of York,
And in the towns as they do march along
Proclaims him king, and many fly to him.
Deraign your battle, for they are at hand.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: I would your Highness would depart the field.
The Queen hath best success when you are absent.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Ay, good my lord, and leave us to our fortune.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Why, that’s my fortune too; therefore I’ll stay.

sp.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
sp.l: Be it with resolution, then, to fight.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.l: My royal father, cheer these noble lords
And hearten those that fight in your defense.
Unsheathe your sword, good father; cry “ Saint George!”

div.stage: March. Enter Edward, Warwick, Richard, George, Norfolk, Montague, and Soldiers, all wearing the white rose.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: Now, perjured Henry, wilt thou kneel for grace
And set thy diadem upon my head,
Or bide the mortal fortune of the field?

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Go rate thy minions, proud insulting boy.
Becomes it thee to be thus bold in terms
Before thy sovereign and thy lawful king?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: I am his king, and he should bow his knee.
I was adopted heir by his consent.
Since when, his oath is broke; for, as I hear,
You that are king, though he do wear the crown,
Have caused him, by new act of Parliament,
To blot out me and put his own son in.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: And reason too:
Who should succeed the father but the son?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Are you there, butcher? O, I cannot speak!

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Ay, crookback, here I stand to answer thee,
Or any he, the proudest of thy sort.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: ’Twas you that killed young Rutland, was it not?

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Ay, and old York, and yet not satisfied.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: For God’s sake, lords, give signal to the fight!

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: What sayst thou, Henry? Wilt thou yield the crown?

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Why, how now, long-tongued Warwick, dare you speak?
When you and I met at Saint Albans last,
Your legs did better service than your hands.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Then ’twas my turn to fly, and now ’tis thine.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: You said so much before, and yet you fled.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: ’Twas not your valor, Clifford, drove me thence.

sp.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
sp.l: No, nor your manhood that durst make you stay.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Northumberland, I hold thee reverently.—
Break off the parley, for scarce I can refrain
The execution of my big-swoll’n heart
Upon that Clifford, that cruel child-killer.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: I slew thy father; call’st thou him a child?

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Ay, like a dastard and a treacherous coward,
As thou didst kill our tender brother Rutland.
But ere sunset I’ll make thee curse the deed.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Have done with words, my lords, and hear me speak.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Defy them, then, or else hold close thy lips.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: I prithee, give no limits to my tongue.
I am a king and privileged to speak.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: My liege, the wound that bred this meeting here
Cannot be cured by words; therefore, be still.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Then, executioner, unsheathe thy sword.
By Him that made us all, I am resolved
That Clifford’s manhood lies upon his tongue.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: Say, Henry, shall I have my right or no?
A thousand men have broke their fasts today
That ne’er shall dine unless thou yield the crown.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: If thou deny, their blood upon thy head,
For York in justice puts his armor on.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.l: If that be right which Warwick says is right,
There is no wrong, but everything is right.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Whoever got thee, there thy mother stands,
For well I wot thou hast thy mother’s tongue.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: But thou art neither like thy sire nor dam,
But like a foul misshapen stigmatic,
Marked by the Destinies to be avoided,
As venom toads or lizards’ dreadful stings.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Iron of Naples, hid with English gilt,
Whose father bears the title of a king,
As if a channel should be called the sea,
Sham’st thou not, knowing whence thou art extraught,
To let thy tongue detect thy baseborn heart?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: A wisp of straw were worth a thousand crowns
To make this shameless callet know herself.—
Helen of Greece was fairer far than thou,
Although thy husband may be Menelaus;
And ne’er was Agamemnon’s brother wronged
By that false woman as this king by thee.
His father reveled in the heart of France,
And tamed the King, and made the Dauphin stoop;
And had he matched according to his state,
He might have kept that glory to this day.
But when he took a beggar to his bed
And graced thy poor sire with his bridal day,
Even then that sunshine brewed a shower for him
That washed his father’s fortunes forth of France
And heaped sedition on his crown at home.
For what hath broached this tumult but thy pride?
Hadst thou been meek, our title still had slept,
And we, in pity of the gentle king,
Had slipped our claim until another age.

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.l: But when we saw our sunshine made thy spring,
And that thy summer bred us no increase,
We set the axe to thy usurping root;
And though the edge hath something hit ourselves,
Yet know thou, since we have begun to strike,
We’ll never leave till we have hewn thee down
Or bathed thy growing with our heated bloods.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: And in this resolution, I defy thee,
Not willing any longer conference,
Since thou denied’st the gentle king to speak.—
Sound, trumpets! Let our bloody colors wave;
And either victory or else a grave!

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Stay, Edward!

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: No, wrangling woman, we’ll no longer stay.
These words will cost ten thousand lives this day.

div.head: Scene 3

stage.stage: Enter Warwick, wearing the white rose.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Forspent with toil, as runners with a race,
I lay me down a little while to breathe,
For strokes received and many blows repaid
Have robbed my strong-knit sinews of their strength;
And spite of spite, needs must I rest awhile.

div.stage: Enter Edward, wearing the white rose, running.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: Smile, gentle heaven, or strike, ungentle death,
For this world frowns and Edward’s sun is clouded.

div.stage: Enter George, wearing the white rose.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: How now, my lord, what hap? What hope of good?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.l: Our hap is loss, our hope but sad despair;
Our ranks are broke, and ruin follows us.
What counsel give you? Whither shall we fly?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: Bootless is flight; they follow us with wings,
And weak we are and cannot shun pursuit.

div.stage: Enter Richard, wearing the white rose.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Ah, Warwick, why hast thou withdrawn thyself?
Thy brother’s blood the thirsty earth hath drunk,
Broached with the steely point of Clifford’s lance,
And in the very pangs of death he cried,
Like to a dismal clangor heard from far,
“ Warwick, revenge! Brother, revenge my death!”
So, underneath the belly of their steeds,
That stained their fetlocks in his smoking blood,
The noble gentleman gave up the ghost.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Then let the earth be drunken with our blood!
I’ll kill my horse because I will not fly.
Why stand we like soft-hearted women here,
Wailing our losses whiles the foe doth rage,
And look upon, as if the tragedy
Were played in jest by counterfeiting actors?
Here on my knee I vow to God above
I’ll never pause again, never stand still,
Till either death hath closed these eyes of mine
Or Fortune given me measure of revenge.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: O Warwick, I do bend my knee with thine,
And in this vow do chain my soul to thine
And, ere my knee rise from the Earth’s cold face,
I throw my hands, mine eyes, my heart to Thee,
Thou setter up and plucker down of kings,
Beseeching Thee, if with Thy will it stands
That to my foes this body must be prey,
Yet that Thy brazen gates of heaven may ope
And give sweet passage to my sinful soul.
Now, lords, take leave until we meet again,
Where’er it be, in heaven or in Earth.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Brother, give me thy hand.— And, gentle Warwick,
Let me embrace thee in my weary arms.
I that did never weep now melt with woe
That winter should cut off our springtime so.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Away, away! Once more, sweet lords, farewell.

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.l: Yet let us all together to our troops
And give them leave to fly that will not stay,
And call them pillars that will stand to us;
And, if we thrive, promise them such rewards
As victors wear at the Olympian Games.
This may plant courage in their quailing breasts,
For yet is hope of life and victory.
Forslow no longer; make we hence amain.

stage.stage: Enter, at separate doors, Richard wearing the white rose, and Clifford, wearing the red rose.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Now, Clifford, I have singled thee alone.
Suppose this arm is for the Duke of York,
And this for Rutland, both bound to revenge,
Wert thou environed with a brazen wall.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Now, Richard, I am with thee here alone.
This is the hand that stabbed thy father York,
And this the hand that slew thy brother Rutland,
And here’s the heart that triumphs in their death
And cheers these hands that slew thy sire and brother
To execute the like upon thyself.
And so, have at thee!

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Nay, Warwick, single out some other chase,
For I myself will hunt this wolf to death.

div.head: Scene 5
div.stage: Alarum. Enter King Henry alone, wearing the red rose.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: This battle fares like to the morning’s war,
When dying clouds contend with growing light,
What time the shepherd, blowing of his nails,
Can neither call it perfect day nor night.
Now sways it this way, like a mighty sea
Forced by the tide to combat with the wind;
Now sways it that way, like the selfsame sea
Forced to retire by fury of the wind.
Sometime the flood prevails, and then the wind;
Now one the better, then another best,
Both tugging to be victors, breast to breast,
Yet neither conqueror nor conquerèd.
So is the equal poise of this fell war.
Here on this molehill will I sit me down.
sp.stage: He sits on a small prominence.
sp.l: To whom God will, there be the victory;
For Margaret my queen and Clifford too
Have chid me from the battle, swearing both
They prosper best of all when I am thence.
Would I were dead, if God’s good will were so,
For what is in this world but grief and woe?
O God! Methinks it were a happy life
To be no better than a homely swain,
To sit upon a hill as I do now,
To carve out dials quaintly, point by point,
Thereby to see the minutes how they run:
How many makes the hour full complete,
How many hours brings about the day,
How many days will finish up the year,
How many years a mortal man may live.
When this is known, then to divide the times:
So many hours must I tend my flock,
So many hours must I take my rest,
So many hours must I contemplate,
So many hours must I sport myself,
So many days my ewes have been with young,
So many weeks ere the poor fools will ean,
So many years ere I shall shear the fleece;
So minutes, hours, days, months, and years,
Passed over to the end they were created,
Would bring white hairs unto a quiet grave.
Ah, what a life were this! How sweet, how lovely!
Gives not the hawthorn bush a sweeter shade
To shepherds looking on their silly sheep
Than doth a rich embroidered canopy
To kings that fear their subjects’ treachery?
O yes, it doth, a thousandfold it doth.
And to conclude, the shepherd’s homely curds,
His cold thin drink out of his leather bottle,
His wonted sleep under a fresh tree’s shade,
All which secure and sweetly he enjoys,
Is far beyond a prince’s delicates—
His viands sparkling in a golden cup,
His body couchèd in a curious bed—
When care, mistrust, and treason waits on him.

div.stage: Alarum. Enter at one door a Son that hath killed his Father, carrying the body.

sp.speaker: SON
sp.l: Ill blows the wind that profits nobody.
This man, whom hand to hand I slew in fight,
May be possessèd with some store of crowns,
And I, that haply take them from him now,
May yet ere night yield both my life and them
To some man else, as this dead man doth me.
Who’s this? O God! It is my father’s face,
Whom in this conflict I unwares have killed.
O heavy times, begetting such events!
From London by the King was I pressed forth.
My father, being the Earl of Warwick’s man,
Came on the part of York, pressed by his master.
And I, who at his hands received my life,
Have by my hands of life bereavèd him.
Pardon me, God, I knew not what I did;
And pardon, father, for I knew not thee.
My tears shall wipe away these bloody marks,
And no more words till they have flowed their fill.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: O piteous spectacle! O bloody times!
Whiles lions war and battle for their dens,
Poor harmless lambs abide their enmity.
Weep, wretched man. I’ll aid thee tear for tear,
And let our hearts and eyes, like civil war,
Be blind with tears and break, o’ercharged with grief.

div.stage: Enter at another door a Father that hath killed his Son, bearing of his Son’s body.

sp.speaker: FATHER
sp.l: Thou that so stoutly hath resisted me,
Give me thy gold, if thou hast any gold,
For I have bought it with an hundred blows.
But let me see: is this our foeman’s face?
Ah, no, no, no, it is mine only son!
Ah, boy, if any life be left in thee,
Throw up thine eye! See, see, what showers arise,
Blown with the windy tempest of my heart
Upon thy wounds, that kills mine eye and heart!
O, pity God this miserable age!
What stratagems, how fell, how butcherly,
Erroneous, mutinous, and unnatural
This deadly quarrel daily doth beget!
O, boy, thy father gave thee life too soon,
And hath bereft thee of thy life too late!

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Woe above woe, grief more than common grief!
O, that my death would stay these ruthful deeds!
O pity, pity, gentle heaven, pity!
The red rose and the white are on his face,
The fatal colors of our striving houses;
The one his purple blood right well resembles,
The other his pale cheeks methinks presenteth.
Wither one rose and let the other flourish;
If you contend, a thousand lives must wither.

sp.speaker: SON
sp.l: How will my mother for a father’s death
Take on with me and ne’er be satisfied!

sp.speaker: FATHER
sp.l: How will my wife for slaughter of my son
Shed seas of tears and ne’er be satisfied!

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: How will the country for these woeful chances
Misthink the King and not be satisfied!

sp.speaker: SON
sp.l: Was ever son so rued a father’s death?

sp.speaker: FATHER
sp.l: Was ever father so bemoaned his son?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Was ever king so grieved for subjects’ woe?
Much is your sorrow, mine ten times so much.

sp.speaker: SON
sp.l: I’ll bear thee hence, where I may weep my fill.

sp.speaker: FATHER
sp.l: These arms of mine shall be thy winding-sheet;
My heart, sweet boy, shall be thy sepulcher,
For from my heart thine image ne’er shall go.
My sighing breast shall be thy funeral bell;
And so obsequious will thy father be
E’en for the loss of thee, having no more,
As Priam was for all his valiant sons.
I’ll bear thee hence, and let them fight that will,
For I have murdered where I should not kill.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Sad-hearted men, much overgone with care,
Here sits a king more woeful than you are.

stage.stage: Enter Queen Margaret, Prince Edward, and Exeter, all wearing the red rose.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.l: Fly, father, fly, for all your friends are fled,
And Warwick rages like a chafèd bull.
Away, for Death doth hold us in pursuit.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.l: Mount you, my lord; towards Berwick post amain.
Edward and Richard, like a brace of greyhounds
Having the fearful flying hare in sight,
With fiery eyes sparkling for very wrath
And bloody steel grasped in their ireful hands,
Are at our backs, and therefore hence amain.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: Away, for Vengeance comes along with them.
Nay, stay not to expostulate, make speed;
Or else come after; I’ll away before.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Nay, take me with thee, good sweet Exeter;
Not that I fear to stay, but love to go
Whither the Queen intends. Forward, away!

div.head: Scene 6
div.stage: A loud alarum. Enter Clifford, wearing the red rose, wounded.

sp.speaker: CLIFFORD
sp.l: Here burns my candle out; ay, here it dies,
Which whiles it lasted gave King Henry light.
O Lancaster, I fear thy overthrow
More than my body’s parting with my soul!
My love and fear glued many friends to thee;
And now I fall, thy tough commixtures melts,
Impairing Henry, strength’ning misproud York;
And whither fly the gnats but to the sun?
And who shines now but Henry’s enemies?
O Phoebus, hadst thou never given consent
That Phaëton should check thy fiery steeds,
Thy burning car never had scorched the Earth!
And Henry, hadst thou swayed as kings should do,
Or as thy father and his father did,
Giving no ground unto the house of York,
They never then had sprung like summer flies;
I and ten thousand in this luckless realm
Had left no mourning widows for our death,
And thou this day hadst kept thy chair in peace.
For what doth cherish weeds but gentle air?
And what makes robbers bold but too much lenity?
Bootless are plaints, and cureless are my wounds;
No way to fly, no strength to hold out flight.
The foe is merciless and will not pity,
For at their hands I have deserved no pity.
The air hath got into my deadly wounds,
And much effuse of blood doth make me faint.
Come, York and Richard, Warwick and the rest.
I stabbed your fathers’ bosoms; split my breast.

div.stage: Alarum and retreat. Enter Edward, Warwick, Richard, and Soldiers, Montague, and George, all wearing the white rose.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: Now breathe we, lords. Good fortune bids us pause
And smooth the frowns of war with peaceful looks.
Some troops pursue the bloody-minded queen
That led calm Henry, though he were a king,
As doth a sail filled with a fretting gust
Command an argosy to stem the waves.
But think you, lords, that Clifford fled with them?

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: No, ’tis impossible he should escape,
For, though before his face I speak the words,
Your brother Richard marked him for the grave,
And wheresoe’er he is, he’s surely dead.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Whose soul is that which takes her heavy leave?
A deadly groan, like life and death’s departing.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: See who it is; and, now the battle’s ended,
If friend or foe, let him be gently used.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Revoke that doom of mercy, for ’tis Clifford,
Who not contented that he lopped the branch
In hewing Rutland when his leaves put forth,
But set his murd’ring knife unto the root
From whence that tender spray did sweetly spring,
I mean our princely father, Duke of York.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: From off the gates of York fetch down the head,
Your father’s head, which Clifford placèd there;
Instead whereof let this supply the room.
Measure for measure must be answerèd.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: Bring forth that fatal screech owl to our house
That nothing sung but death to us and ours;
Now death shall stop his dismal threat’ning sound,
And his ill-boding tongue no more shall speak.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: I think his understanding is bereft.—
Speak, Clifford, dost thou know who speaks to thee?—
Dark cloudy death o’ershades his beams of life,
And he nor sees nor hears us what we say.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: O, would he did— and so, perhaps, he doth!
’Tis but his policy to counterfeit,
Because he would avoid such bitter taunts
Which in the time of death he gave our father.

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.l: If so thou think’st, vex him with eager words.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Clifford, ask mercy and obtain no grace.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: Clifford, repent in bootless penitence.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Clifford, devise excuses for thy faults.

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.l: While we devise fell tortures for thy faults.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Thou didst love York, and I am son to York.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: Thou pitied’st Rutland; I will pity thee.

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.l: Where’s Captain Margaret to fence you now?

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: They mock thee, Clifford; swear as thou wast wont.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: What, not an oath? Nay, then, the world goes hard
When Clifford cannot spare his friends an oath.
I know by that he’s dead; and, by my soul,
If this right hand would buy but two hours’ life
That I in all despite might rail at him,
This hand should chop it off, and with the issuing blood
Stifle the villain whose unstaunchèd thirst
York and young Rutland could not satisfy.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Ay, but he’s dead. Off with the traitor’s head,
And rear it in the place your father’s stands.
And now to London with triumphant march,
There to be crownèd England’s royal king,
From whence shall Warwick cut the sea to France
And ask the Lady Bona for thy queen;
So shalt thou sinew both these lands together,
And having France thy friend, thou shalt not dread
The scattered foe that hopes to rise again;
For though they cannot greatly sting to hurt,
Yet look to have them buzz to offend thine ears.
First will I see the coronation,
And then to Brittany I’ll cross the sea
To effect this marriage, so it please my lord.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.l: Even as thou wilt, sweet Warwick, let it be;
For in thy shoulder do I build my seat,
And never will I undertake the thing
Wherein thy counsel and consent is wanting.—
Richard, I will create thee Duke of Gloucester,
And George, of Clarence. Warwick as ourself
Shall do and undo as him pleaseth best.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Let me be Duke of Clarence, George of Gloucester,
For Gloucester’s dukedom is too ominous.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Tut, that’s a foolish observation.
Richard, be Duke of Gloucester. Now to London,
To see these honors in possession.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter two Gamekeepers, with crossbows in their hands.

sp.speaker: FIRST GAMEKEEPER
sp.l: Under this thick-grown brake we’ll shroud ourselves,
For through this laund anon the deer will come;
And in this covert will we make our stand,
Culling the principal of all the deer.

sp.speaker: SECOND GAMEKEEPER
sp.l: I’ll stay above the hill, so both may shoot.

sp.speaker: FIRST GAMEKEEPER
sp.l: That cannot be. The noise of thy crossbow
Will scare the herd, and so my shoot is lost.
Here stand we both, and aim we at the best.
And for the time shall not seem tedious,
I’ll tell thee what befell me on a day
In this self place where now we mean to stand.

sp.speaker: SECOND GAMEKEEPER
sp.l: Here comes a man; let’s stay till he be past.

div.stage: Enter King Henry, in disguise, with a prayer book.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: From Scotland am I stol’n, even of pure love,
To greet mine own land with my wishful sight.
No, Harry, Harry, ’tis no land of thine!
Thy place is filled, thy scepter wrung from thee,
Thy balm washed off wherewith thou wast anointed.
No bending knee will call thee Caesar now,
No humble suitors press to speak for right,
No, not a man comes for redress of thee;
For how can I help them an not myself?

sp.speaker: FIRST GAMEKEEPER
sp.l: Ay, here’s a deer whose skin’s a keeper’s fee.
This is the quondam king. Let’s seize upon him.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Let me embrace the sour adversaries,
For wise men say it is the wisest course.

sp.speaker: SECOND GAMEKEEPER
sp.l: Why linger we? Let us lay hands upon him.

sp.speaker: FIRST GAMEKEEPER
sp.l: Forbear awhile; we’ll hear a little more.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: My queen and son are gone to France for aid,
And, as I hear, the great commanding Warwick
Is thither gone to crave the French king’s sister
To wife for Edward. If this news be true,
Poor queen and son, your labor is but lost,
For Warwick is a subtle orator,
And Lewis a prince soon won with moving words.
By this account, then, Margaret may win him,
For she’s a woman to be pitied much.
Her sighs will make a batt’ry in his breast,
Her tears will pierce into a marble heart.
The tiger will be mild whiles she doth mourn,
And Nero will be tainted with remorse
To hear and see her plaints, her brinish tears.
Ay, but she’s come to beg, Warwick to give;
She on his left side craving aid for Henry;
He on his right asking a wife for Edward.
She weeps and says her Henry is deposed;
He smiles and says his Edward is installed;
That she, poor wretch, for grief can speak no more,
Whiles Warwick tells his title, smooths the wrong,
Inferreth arguments of mighty strength,
And in conclusion wins the King from her
With promise of his sister and what else
To strengthen and support King Edward’s place.
O Margaret, thus ’twill be, and thou, poor soul,
Art then forsaken, as thou went’st forlorn.

sp.speaker: SECOND GAMEKEEPER
sp.l: Say, what art thou that talk’st of kings and queens?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: More than I seem, and less than I was born to:
A man at least, for less I should not be;
And men may talk of kings, and why not I?

sp.speaker: SECOND GAMEKEEPER
sp.l: Ay, but thou talk’st as if thou wert a king.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Why, so I am in mind, and that’s enough.

sp.speaker: SECOND GAMEKEEPER
sp.l: But if thou be a king, where is thy crown?

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: My crown is in my heart, not on my head;
Not decked with diamonds and Indian stones,
Nor to be seen. My crown is called content;
A crown it is that seldom kings enjoy.

sp.speaker: SECOND GAMEKEEPER
sp.l: Well, if you be a king crowned with content,
Your crown content and you must be contented
To go along with us. For, as we think,
You are the king King Edward hath deposed;
And we his subjects sworn in all allegiance
Will apprehend you as his enemy.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: But did you never swear and break an oath?

sp.speaker: SECOND GAMEKEEPER
sp.l: No, never such an oath, nor will not now.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Where did you dwell when I was King of England?

sp.speaker: SECOND GAMEKEEPER
sp.l: Here in this country, where we now remain.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: I was anointed king at nine months old.
My father and my grandfather were kings,
And you were sworn true subjects unto me.
And tell me, then, have you not broke your oaths?

sp.speaker: FIRST GAMEKEEPER
sp.l: No, for we were subjects but while you were king.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Why, am I dead? Do I not breathe a man?
Ah, simple men, you know not what you swear.
Look as I blow this feather from my face
And as the air blows it to me again,
Obeying with my wind when I do blow
And yielding to another when it blows,
Commanded always by the greater gust,
Such is the lightness of you common men.
But do not break your oaths, for of that sin
My mild entreaty shall not make you guilty.
Go where you will, the King shall be commanded,
And be you kings: command, and I’ll obey.

sp.speaker: FIRST GAMEKEEPER
sp.l: We are true subjects to the King, King Edward.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: So would you be again to Henry
If he were seated as King Edward is.

sp.speaker: FIRST GAMEKEEPER
sp.l: We charge you in God’s name and the King’s
To go with us unto the officers.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: In God’s name, lead. Your king’s name be obeyed,
And what God will, that let your king perform.
And what he will, I humbly yield unto.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter King Edward, Richard, Duke of Gloucester, George, Duke of Clarence, Lady Grey, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: Brother of Gloucester, at Saint Albans field
This lady’s husband, Sir Richard Grey, was slain,
His land then seized on by the conqueror.
Her suit is now to repossess those lands,
Which we in justice cannot well deny,
Because in quarrel of the house of York
The worthy gentleman did lose his life.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Your Highness shall do well to grant her suit;
It were dishonor to deny it her.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: It were no less, but yet I’ll make a pause.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Yea, is it so?
I see the lady hath a thing to grant
Before the King will grant her humble suit.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.l: He knows the game; how true he keeps the wind!

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Silence!

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: Widow, we will consider of your suit,
And come some other time to know our mind.

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: Right gracious lord, I cannot brook delay.
May it please your Highness to resolve me now,
And what your pleasure is shall satisfy me.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Ay, widow? Then I’ll warrant you all your lands,
An if what pleases him shall pleasure you.
Fight closer, or, good faith, you’ll catch a blow.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.l: I fear her not, unless she chance to fall.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: God forbid that, for he’ll take vantages.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: How many children hast thou, widow? Tell me.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.l: I think he means to beg a child of her.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Nay, then, whip me; he’ll rather give her two.

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: Three, my most gracious lord.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: You shall have four if you’ll be ruled by him.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: ’Twere pity they should lose their father’s lands.

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: Be pitiful, dread lord, and grant it then.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: Lords, give us leave. I’ll try this widow’s wit.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: Ay, good leave have you, for you will have leave
Till youth take leave and leave you to the crutch.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: Now tell me, madam, do you love your children?

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: Ay, full as dearly as I love myself.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: And would you not do much to do them good?

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: To do them good I would sustain some harm.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: Then get your husband’s lands to do them good.

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: Therefore I came unto your Majesty.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: I’ll tell you how these lands are to be got.

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: So shall you bind me to your Highness’ service.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: What service wilt thou do me if I give them?

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: What you command that rests in me to do.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: But you will take exceptions to my boon.

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: No, gracious lord, except I cannot do it.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: Ay, but thou canst do what I mean to ask.

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: Why, then, I will do what your Grace commands.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: He plies her hard, and much rain wears the marble.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.l: As red as fire! Nay, then, her wax must melt.

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: Why stops my lord? Shall I not hear my task?

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: An easy task; ’tis but to love a king.

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: That’s soon performed because I am a subject.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: Why, then, thy husband’s lands I freely give thee.

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: I take my leave with many thousand thanks.

div.stage: She curtsies and begins to exit.

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.l: The match is made; she seals it with a cursy.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: But stay thee; ’tis the fruits of love I mean.

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: The fruits of love I mean, my loving liege.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: Ay, but, I fear me, in another sense.
What love, think’st thou, I sue so much to get?

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: My love till death, my humble thanks, my prayers,
That love which virtue begs and virtue grants.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: No, by my troth, I did not mean such love.

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: Why, then, you mean not as I thought you did.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: But now you partly may perceive my mind.

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: My mind will never grant what I perceive
Your Highness aims at, if I aim aright.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: To tell thee plain, I aim to lie with thee.

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: To tell you plain, I had rather lie in prison.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: Why, then, thou shalt not have thy husband’s lands.

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: Why, then, mine honesty shall be my dower,
For by that loss I will not purchase them.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD
sp.l: Therein thou wrong’st thy children mightily.

sp.speaker: LADY GREY
sp.l: Herein your Highness wrongs both them and me.
But, mighty lord, this merry inclination
Accords not with the sadness of my suit.
